<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning.</strong> Apparently the hot new thing among transportation agencies is to have people vote on punny names for their snow plow fleets.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Scotland’s been doing it since 2006 with tremendous results (Buzz Iceclear, Lord Coldemort, Creedence Clear-Road Revival), and last week Minnesota’s DOT announced the winners of its own Name-A-Snowplow contest:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Betty Whiteout was the runaway winner, followed by Ctrl Salt Delete and The Big Leplowski.</span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Our entry for next year: Snow More Mr. Ice Guy </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">—<em>Neal Freyman</em></p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GEOPOLITICS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/06/undefined?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Europe prepares for a gaslighting
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/06/undefined?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="Empty fuel pumps at an Esso petrol station" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/05b759c19e7d29f0c932d27919c4ee15249bb438-1024x683.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Dan Kitwood/Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">To kick off the week, let’s head to the Russia–Ukraine border, where Russia has amassed <a href="https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-joe-biden-business-national-security-jake-sullivan-4f766b3b07014bddb9006d44a9f240b8?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">at least 70%</a> of the military capacity it needs to invade its neighbor, the US government said this weekend.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That means, in the words of National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan yesterday, a move into Ukraine “could happen as soon as tomorrow or it could take some weeks yet.”</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The US has estimated that a war could leave 50,000 civilians killed or wounded, 25,000 Ukrainian soldiers dead, and millions of refugees looking for shelter across Europe.</span></li></ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">It could also could sap Europe of energy</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Among the scenarios keeping world leaders up at night is the possibility that Russia could cut off energy supplies to Europe.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How that would play out: </strong>If Russia invades, the US has vowed to unleash “the mother of all sanctions” against the country. Russia, in retaliation, could counter with its own mother lode—withholding gas shipments to Europe.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Which…would not be good, given Europe has a coffee-level <a href="https://www.cfr.org/in-brief/russias-energy-role-europe-whats-stake-ukraine-crisis?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">dependence</a> on Russian energy.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Russia supplies about 33% of Europe’s natural gas, and more than 25% of its crude oil imports.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Germany, in one extreme example, relies on Russia for more than half of its natural gas.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Putting Europe in an even more vulnerable position is the fact that consumers are already being squeezed by record energy prices. 22 million households in Britain will see their gas and electricity bill spike 54% come April, an energy regulator warned.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What can be done? </strong>Not a whole lot. One hope is that Russia won’t cut off all gas shipments, because that move could be just as damaging to its own economy as it would be to the rest of Europe. Still, Europe is exploring importing more gas from other countries in case Russia shuts off the spigot.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead…</strong>leaders will be holding two separate high-stakes meetings today centered on the Ukraine conflict. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz is in Washington, DC, to meet with President Biden, and French President Emmanuel Macron will meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Moscow. Macron said he thinks it’s possible to avoid a war.</p>
</div>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/06/spotify-quietly-removes-more-than-70-joe-rogan-podcast-episodes?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Rogan episodes go poof
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/06/spotify-quietly-removes-more-than-70-joe-rogan-podcast-episodes?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="Joe Rogan" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/77262ddafe60876264d1ddf101041e812ef83926-4202x2802.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Alex Trautwig/Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Spotify has <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/05/arts/music/joe-rogan-spotify-apology-slur.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">scrubbed</a> as many as 70 episodes of <em>The Joe Rogan Experience</em> podcast after a video compilation showed Rogan using the N-word in past episodes spanning 12 years.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In a <a href="https://twitter.com/sarafischer/status/1490511979819278339?s=20&t=D_ki82XWy2Np3GLAwKT_dQ" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">note to employees</a> obtained by Axios, Spotify CEO Daniel Ek said that Rogan “chose to remove a number of episodes from Spotify” due to his racially insensitive language. Rogan issued his own apology on Instagram over the weekend:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The podcaster said those clips looked “horrible, even to me” and said this was “the most regretful and shameful thing that I’ve ever had to talk about publicly.”</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“It’s not my word to use,” Rogan added.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>As more artists pull their music from Spotify over its relationship with Rogan, Ek continues to stand by him. “While I strongly condemn what Joe has said…I do not believe that silencing Joe is the answer,” he said. “Looking at the issue more broadly, it’s critical thinking and open debate that powers real and necessary progress.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Ek also said he’d commit $100 million (perhaps uncoincidentally the value of Rogan’s deal with Spotify) for the licensing, development, and marketing of music and audio content from marginalized groups.</p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FITNESS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/06/amazon-nike-among-companies-rumored-to-be-interested-in-buying-peloton?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Who should buy Peloton?
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/06/amazon-nike-among-companies-rumored-to-be-interested-in-buying-peloton?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="A Peloton framed as a skeleton " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/1b619d7992374f2310f90b38a065266db5f97a9b-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Dianna "Mick" McDougall</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Like most fitness equipment, Peloton has ended up as garage sale browsing fodder.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/peloton-draws-interest-from-potential-suitors-including-amazon-11644012693?mod=hp_lista_pos3" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Multiple</a> <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/8ae3240b-8c09-48e4-bc2c-b7a9e4c00c51?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reports</a> out Friday revealed that several companies—namely Amazon and Nike—were considering a purchase of the at-home fitness maker.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In general, Peloton makes an attractive takeover target because it’s on decent financial footing, boasts a highly loyal user base, and has become much cheaper due to its recent stock plunge (down nearly 85% from its 2020 peak). So why would it make sense for Amazon or Nike?</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><strong style="color:#000">Amazon: </strong></span><span>Peloton would give Amazon a bigger foothold in the wellness area, which it’s already exploring with its Halo fitness band. Amazon could also lend its supply chain expertise to shore up Peloton’s logistics woes, and perhaps bundle a Peloton subscription into its Prime membership.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><strong style="color:#000">Nike: </strong></span><span>Buying Peloton would represent a bold pivot by the company from fitness tech software to hardware. But the brand fit is there, Axios </span><span><a href="https://www.axios.com/peloton-foley-investments-earnings-de8837fa-0317-4216-a781-f72486b00819.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">notes</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Other potential buyers have also been floated, including the usual suspects Apple, Google, Netflix, Microsoft, or a private equity firm.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Still, any deal is contingent on the support of Peloton CEO John Foley, who has a tight grip on the board’s voting power. He’d have to be in a truly despairing mood to sell the company he co-founded in 2012.</p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CALENDAR
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/06/the-week-ahead-february-7?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
The week ahead
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Inflation: </strong>The <a href="https://www.reuters.com/business/wall-st-week-ahead-inflation-data-next-focus-investors-after-bond-yield-spike-2022-02-04/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">monthly inflation report</a> we’ve all come to dread will drop on Thursday, and it’s once again expected to be quite dreadful. Consumer prices are projected to have jumped 0.5% from the previous month and 7.3% over the past year—which would be the biggest increase since 1982.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Earnings:</strong> Last week’s earnings reports resulted in violent swings in stock prices, from Snap’s 59% gain to Meta’s 26% wipeout. The companies <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2022/02/04/fresh-inflation-data-could-fuel-further-market-volatility-in-the-week-ahead.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reporting</a> this week—Pfizer, Disney, Coca-Cola, Pepsi, Twitter, and Zillow among them—know that in <em>this </em>market, any small stain on their financials could lead to a stock plunge.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Olympics: </strong>The 2022 Beijing Games enter their first full week. Here’s the current <a href="https://www.nbcolympics.com/medals?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">medal count</a>, and here’s the <a href="https://www.inquirer.com/sports/nbc-olympics-tv-schedule-live-streaming-february-7-20220206.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">TV schedule for today,</a> which includes Nathan Chen in the men’s figure skating short program and a US–Canada women’s hockey battle.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Everything else:</strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Academy Award nominees will be announced Tuesday.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>New York Fashion Week begins on Friday.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The Super Bowl between the Bengals and Rams is on Sunday. Expect a lot of </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/bengals-rams-and-bitcoin-crypto-ads-invade-the-super-bowl-11644159817?mod=hp_lista_pos2" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">crypto ads</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
</ul>
</div>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>Chanel has <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/chanel-tests-purse-lovers-with-3-000-price-hikes-11644057005?redirect=amp" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">raised the price</a> of its Classic Flap bag by $3,000 since 2019, from $5,200 to $8,200. The entire luxury sector has been jacking up prices during the pandemic but, despite a few grumblings, it appears wealthy buyers aren’t fazed. “We’ve seen absolutely no consumer resistance to any of the price increases that we have taken, and there will be more,” John Idol, the CEO of Versace owner Capri, said recently.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“You come with a smile on your face, and you leave with a bigger smile on your face.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Andy Johnson is the founder of Love Cloud, a company that will take you and your partner on a private, 45-minute <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/05/style/love-cloud-las-vegas-mile-high-club.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Mile High Club Flight</a> for $995. Yes, it’s exactly what it sounds like, complete with a twin mattress, pillows, and a pilot who wears noise-canceling headphones.</p>

collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eTo kick off the week, let’s head to the Russia–Ukraine border, where Russia has amassed \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-joe-biden-business-national-security-jake-sullivan-4f766b3b07014bddb9006d44a9f240b8?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eat least 70%\u003c/a\u003e of the military capacity it needs to invade its neighbor, the US government said this weekend.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat means, in the words of National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan yesterday, a move into Ukraine “could happen as soon as tomorrow or it could take some weeks yet.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe US has estimated that a war could leave 50,000 civilians killed or wounded, 25,000 Ukrainian soldiers dead, and millions of refugees looking for shelter across Europe.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIt could also could sap Europe of energy\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAmong the scenarios keeping world leaders up at night is the possibility that Russia could cut off energy supplies to Europe.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow that would play out: \u003c/strong\u003eIf Russia invades, the US has vowed to unleash “the mother of all sanctions” against the country. Russia, in retaliation, could counter with its own mother lode—withholding gas shipments to Europe.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhich…would not be good, given Europe has a coffee-level \u003ca href=\"https://www.cfr.org/in-brief/russias-energy-role-europe-whats-stake-ukraine-crisis?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edependence\u003c/a\u003e on Russian energy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eRussia supplies about 33% of Europe’s natural gas, and more than 25% of its crude oil imports.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eGermany, in one extreme example, relies on Russia for more than half of its natural gas.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePutting Europe in an even more vulnerable position is the fact that consumers are already being squeezed by record energy prices. 22 million households in Britain will see their gas and electricity bill spike 54% come April, an energy regulator warned.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat can be done? \u003c/strong\u003eNot a whole lot. One hope is that Russia won’t cut off all gas shipments, because that move could be just as damaging to its own economy as it would be to the rest of Europe. Still, Europe is exploring importing more gas from other countries in case Russia shuts off the spigot.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead…\u003c/strong\u003eleaders will be holding two separate high-stakes meetings today centered on the Ukraine conflict. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz is in Washington, DC, to meet with President Biden, and French President Emmanuel Macron will meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Moscow. Macron said he thinks it’s possible to avoid a war.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSpotify has \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/05/arts/music/joe-rogan-spotify-apology-slur.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003escrubbed\u003c/a\u003e as many as 70 episodes of \u003cem\u003eThe Joe Rogan Experience\u003c/em\u003e podcast after a video compilation showed Rogan using the N-word in past episodes spanning 12 years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn a \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/sarafischer/status/1490511979819278339?s=20\u0026t=D_ki82XWy2Np3GLAwKT_dQ\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enote to employees\u003c/a\u003e obtained by Axios, Spotify CEO Daniel Ek said that Rogan “chose to remove a number of episodes from Spotify” due to his racially insensitive language. Rogan issued his own apology on Instagram over the weekend:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe podcaster said those clips looked “horrible, even to me” and said this was “the most regretful and shameful thing that I’ve ever had to talk about publicly.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“It’s not my word to use,” Rogan added.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eAs more artists pull their music from Spotify over its relationship with Rogan, Ek continues to stand by him. “While I strongly condemn what Joe has said…I do not believe that silencing Joe is the answer,” he said. “Looking at the issue more broadly, it’s critical thinking and open debate that powers real and necessary progress.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eEk also said he’d commit $100 million (perhaps uncoincidentally the value of Rogan’s deal with Spotify) for the licensing, development, and marketing of music and audio content from marginalized groups.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" the at-home fitness maker.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn general, Peloton makes an attractive takeover target because it’s on decent financial footing, boasts a highly loyal user base, and has become much cheaper due to its recent stock plunge (down nearly 85% from its 2020 peak). So why would it make sense for Amazon or Nike?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAmazon: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePeloton would give Amazon a bigger foothold in the wellness area, which it’s already exploring with its Halo fitness band. Amazon could also lend its supply chain expertise to shore up Peloton’s logistics woes, and perhaps bundle a Peloton subscription into its Prime membership.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eNike: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBuying Peloton would represent a bold pivot by the company from fitness tech software to hardware. But the brand fit is there, Axios \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/peloton-foley-investments-earnings-de8837fa-0317-4216-a781-f72486b00819.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enotes\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOther potential buyers have also been floated, including the usual suspects Apple, Google, Netflix, Microsoft, or a private equity firm.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eStill, any deal is contingent on the support of Peloton CEO John Foley, who has a tight grip on the board’s voting power. He’d have to be in a truly despairing mood to sell the company he co-founded in 2012.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\"
